thread.title: Developers, data scientists among hot jobs of 2023
thread.title_full: Developers, data scientists among hot jobs of 2023 | The Straits Times

author: Cheow Sue-Ann
title: Developers, data scientists among hot jobs of 2023
text:
SINGAPORE - Technology and finance specialists seeking jobs are in a sweet spot for 2024, with strong demand for positions in their areas.
Data on job vacancies in Singapore released by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) on Dec 29 showed that among professionals, the top jobs in demand as at September 2023 are software, Web and multimedia developers – similar to the situation in 2022.
According to the data set, data scientists are another of the occupations in demand, with the second-highest share of vacancies within the information and communications technology (ICT) sector.
Among managerial roles, the highest demand is for business and sales positions, including business development, budgeting and financial accounting, sales as well as marketing.
For graduate job seekers with degree-level qualifications and above, the top three jobs in demand are software, web and multimedia developers; budgeting and financial accounting managers; and business development managers.
In the associate professionals and technicians group, the top three jobs are commercial and marketing sales executives; pre-primary education teachers; and operations officers, excluding those in transport operations.
The data also showed that for rank-and-file positions, the top 10 occupations were fairly similar to last year’s list.
Receptionists as well as customer service and information clerks remain the top jobs in demand. They comprised nearly four in 10 of the vacancies in the clerical and services group.

Ms Chew Siew Mee, managing director of Jobstreet by Seek, told ST that based on the recruitment site’s internal database, ICT, engineering as well as banking and finance sectors topped the charts for the highest number of job postings on its platform in 2023.
She added that this data was corroborated by Jobstreet’s 2023 salary guide, where the banking and finance industry saw a notable 68 per cent surge in job advertisements post-pandemic, alongside a 10 per cent to 34 per cent increase in salaries, particularly at levels below senior management.
According to Jobstreet’s salary report for 2023, there was a 105 per cent surge in job listings for the education sector compared to the previous year, accompanied by an overall salary increase of 21 per cent.
The report, released on Dec 22, also showed that the technology sector continues to offer abundant job prospects and has seen a 16 per cent salary increase compared to pre-pandemic levels. It noted that at the end of 2022, tech professionals were earning a median monthly salary of $7,376, before adding in Central Provident Fund contributions.
Based on available data as well as comments from experts, jobs with a technology focus look set to be in great demand in the new year.
Ms Chew added: “Given the local government’s recent $3.3 billion investment in infocomms technology as well as the cumulative $16 billion investment over the last five years, we are anticipating the employment landscape to continue its strong tech focus with AI being an unmissable topic across all industries.”

New handbook to help S’pore employers hire tech workers based on skills, not academics Associate Professor Wu Pei Chuan from the department of management and organisation at the National University of Singapore’s business school said the jobs in demand in 2023, according to MOM’s data, are unsurprising, with the four main growth sectors being ICT, health and social services, professional services as well as financial services.
And these areas are unlikely to change soon, she said.
Prof Wu said these industries are expected to see a high job demand “because they are more in line with the forecasts of the government and the key areas they are looking to invest in”.
But she also stressed that while the jobs in demand are unlikely to see major change in the coming year, the job scope and skills required are constantly evolving.
She added that while many of the top jobs are highly technical, this does not mean that such jobs are inaccessible to those who are looking to enter from a different industry.
She said: “While technical skills are important to help land a good job, soft skills, agility and a willingness to learn are what will build a secure future. Agility and a willingness to learn are more important to remain relevant in the future.”
